awd_titl_txt: Conference: NEWGA - Northeast Workshop in Geometric Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The inaugural Northeast Workshop in Geometric Analysis (NEWGA) will be hosted at the University of Connecticut, November 5-6, 2022. The workshop will bring together experts who work in various areas of geometric analysis and will encourage the participation of graduate students and recent PhDs in the Northeastern US to foster new developments in geometric analysis. The workshop also aims to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion in science.  Ensuring that members of underrepresented groups are well-represented among plenary speakers is a priority. Special efforts will be made to recruit participants from women and underrepresented minorities.
             
Geometric analysis is a rapidly developing area that has many interconnections to different branches of mathematics. The workshop will connect experts in the topics of Complex Analysis and Geometry, Fully Nonlinear PDEs, General Relativity, and Geometric Flows, and it will enhance collaborations across these areas in the Northeastern US. Besides plenary talks, an Emerging Leader Session is specifically designed to increase the involvement of students and early-career researchers by presenting their research. The workshop webpage is https://s.uconn.edu/newga.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The award supported the Northeast Workshop in Geometric Analysis (NEWGA), held in November 5-6, 2022. Featuring a lineup of 13 speakers. Eight plenary talks were delivered by prominent researchers and experts in the field, providing insights into various topics related to the conference theme. A special session titled "Emerging Leaders" featured 5 short talks presented by graduate students and recent PhDs. This session aimed to showcase the work of junior researchers and provide them with a platform to share their work. 

The speakers covered a diverse range of topics, including Complex Analysis and Geometry, Fully Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations, General Relativity, Geometric Flows. Those topics reflect the interconnecting nature of the field of geometric analysis. This diversity allowed attendees to gain insights from different subfields and broaden their perspectives.

The organization committee made targeted efforts to engage women and underrepresented minorities. The workshop achieved gender parity among plenary speakers, and provided funding to support underrepresented participants.

NEWGA drew an audience around 58 participants, including researchers, postdocs, and graduate students in the upper Northeast. The workshop connected experts across various fields and engaged students and recent PhDs with current research development. The well-structured workshop schedule and breaks allowed speakers and participants to actively participate in discussions, pose questions, and interact, fostering a conducive environment for learning and skill development.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Lan-Hsuan Huang
